   This man presents after experiencing chest pain, with the EMS
   subsequently finding him bradycardic and hypotensive. He appears to
   have developed complete heart block. He was in a hyperosmolar, (likely)
   non-ketotic hyperglycemic state. We hypothesize that this hyperglycemia
   resulted in dramatic hyperkalemia and some hyponatremia, which in turn
   resulted in heart block and junctional rhythm, hypotension and his
   collapse.
   .

   Etiology as described above. Other major differential would be
   infarctive, also consistent with otherwise unexplained chest pain, but
   EKG and enzymes not consistent with infarction. Toxicology  has broadly
   been negative, with metoprolol still pending.
   - Evaluate for ischemia/infarction (see below)
   - Correct laboratory abnormalities (see below) and follow telemetry and
   EKG.
   - F/u toxicology for metoprolol
   - Continue to pace transvenously with lower threshold now in sinus
   rhythm
   - [**Month (only) 8**] need PPM depending on etiology
 unlikely given probably related
   to electrolyte disturbance
   .
   # Hyperkalemia.
   Likely secondary to acute on chronic (as suggested by A1c)
   hyperglycemia. Reduced by insulin/correction of K. [**Month (only) 8**] be total body
   depleted.
   - Insulin sliding scale and 10 units glargine QHS
   - No Kayexelate
   - Continue to supplement potassium as necessary with goal 4
   - TID chemistry for now
   .
   # Respiratory status.
   Sedated and intubated. Presently on AC (40%, 550 cc, 14 BPM, PEEP 5 cm
   H2O). Indication for intubation was combativeness in ED. No indication
   at present, particularly given presenting state resolving.
   - Continue until stable lab values then wean sedation and extubate.
   .
   # Coronary Artery Disease
   Two vessel disease, likely without stents. Ischemic etiology possible,
   particularly if sinus node infarcted. However, enzymes are presently
   flat. LVEF 55% in [**2117**], but may be less now.
   - Cycle enzymes, with one more set
   - Monitor with telemetry
   - Repeat 12 lead EKG
   - Appears to have been on aspirin previously - will restart
   - Restart statin
   - Consider outpatient stress test in future if it is determined that
   heart block was provoked
   - Likely no need for echo at present (as on previous plan)
   .
   # Hypertension
   Hypotensive on arrival. Hypotension seemed somewhat out of proportion
   to bradycardia. Possible that arrhythmic state was missed. Paced and
   hypertensive early, with some resolution of hypertension when pacing
   reduced and developed sinus rhythm. Now hypertensive when sedation
   weaned. Likely hypertension at baseline, but no clear use of
   antihypertensive. Will aim for SBP > 110, given risk of cerebral
   hypoperfusion in this patient who is likely hypertensive at baseline.
   - Hydralazine 10 mg IV q2h prn for SBP > 160 mm Hg
   - Watch today and begin ongoing antihypertensives after extubation.
   .
   # Diabetes/Non-ketotic hyperglycemia hyperosmolar state (326 mOsms)
   Secondary to very poorly controlled hyperglycemia of diabetes II. [**Month (only) 8**]
   have been elevated for some time, per PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 543**] now dramatic enough to
   become symptomatic. A1c consistent with chronic high hyperglycemia.
   Hemoglobin glycosylation is time dependent, so A1c should reflect poor
   control and chronicity more than this acute event.
   - Continue to adjust standing insulin (now glargine 10 mg QHS) and use
   ISS
   - Continue to replete K as necessary
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   Interestingly, patient creatinine at admission was 0.7,  later the same
   day, was 1.3, now 1.5. Seems likely that there was acute injury in
   context of hypotension, but rapid accumulation of creatinine
   impressive. UOP dropped off yesterday to < 15 cc/hr, but now output is
   impressive
 possible ATN. Proteinuria c/w poorly controlled diabetic
   kidney disease.
   - Follow urine Osms and lytes.
   - Microscopy for signs of ATN
   .
   FEN:
   No diet until hyperK and hyperGly resolved, then tube feeds.
   .
